title.narrative: Projet d’Appui a la Sécurisation des Terres et Ouvrages de Réhabilitation des Aires Locales (PASTORAL)

description.narrative:
Mercy Corps' PASTORAL program responds to the continuous emergency situation in Niger following the 2008 food price crisis and the 2009-2010 food crises that left more than 7.8 million people, out of a total population of over 15 million, in need of assistance.
PASTORAL is designed to improve food security of agro-pastoralists and pastoralist households in rural areas of the Filingué region of Niger. The program is composed of four main components including, i) a short-term Cash-for-Work component to mitigate high levels of food insecurity via a quick injection of cash, ii) support for vaccination and treatment of pastoralists’ herds to ensure adequate animal health, iii) nutrition education activities, and iv) prevention and management of risks related to natural hazards and conflicts to build beneficiaries’ resiliency to future shocks. The program also places an emphasis on ensuring that natural resources are protected and that conflicts between farmers and herders are prevented.
The program will reach approximately 7,000 households or 56,000 people. One thousand people are participating in CFW programming and 6,000 people will benefit from livestock care, the animal feed voucher project, nutrition education activities and risk prevention strategies.

The principal activities of the PASTORAL program include the rehabilitation and re-seeding of 200 hectares of grazing lands for increased fodder production; the use of animal feed vouchers to distribute supplementary feed to animals belonging to the most destitute households; the promotion of improved fodder harvest and storage; the rehabilitation of water points; information and communication campaigns on herd management; and nutrition education and monitoring. It is anticipated that these activities will improve overall livestock health, which will lead to increased productivity, milk production and subsequently improve nutrition rates among agro-pastoralist and pastoralists' children along the corridor.
